title: First Gen Growth Mindset: A Mini Memoir
description: Please note that this memoir is very personal. The goal of my blog was not only for it to educate others, but for it to help me learn more about myself. Writing became therapeutic as it helped me understand my emotions, personality and values better. title: Policy In The Alleviation of The Achievement Gap: Head Start
description: In Lyndon B. Johnson’s 1964 State of the Union Address, he shared his vision for a War on Poverty. As part of this, he planned to develop a program to prepare low-income children for elementary school. title: The Psychology of Baby Brain Development
description: The distance from a mother's crooked elbow to the wide eyes of their newborn baby matches the range of the baby's field of vision perfectly. This clever design by nature assures that the baby's brain can easily form neural networks to create an emotional connection to the caregiver. A newborn baby's brain is primed to … Continue reading The Psychology of Baby Brain Development →

title: The Role of Standardized Tests in the Perpetuation of the Achievement Gap
description: In the nineteenth century, eugenicists believed that race determined intelligence, and they created IQ tests to help them confirm this. In a journal from Washington University, civil rights activist W.E.B. DuBois was quoted as saying that these IQ tests were administered to “put black folk absolutely beyond the possibility of civilization” (Au). title: Hope for the Homeless
description: There's nothing better than a carefree stroll down North Chicago. title: The Concept of Race
description: How many races are there? Today, there are almost an undefined number of races: Caucasian, Asian, Hispanic, Latino, Native American, etc. Our idea of race is dynamic, as our definition of it has expanded and evolved over time. Today, we use race in such a way that it has become a significant part of our … Continue reading The Concept of Race →

title: Welcome to The School of Tunah
description: Hi! My name is Tinah Hong. Some fun facts about me: I'm known by some of my friends as Tunah.
